transcript.text: What is "Life"?
A very beautiful philosophic and scientific question!
What is the difference between what is alive, and what is not?
Interestingly, a 10 yo child would not have any issue to give an answer.
Show him some pictures, and he will tell you that a cat and a tree are alive, which is not the case of the rock and the trumpet.
What is alive? Well, isn't it obvious?
But is it really that simple?
Let us take a look at few complicated cases
This coral for example.
Despite its rocky appearance, it is in fact a living organism.
And it is not even a plant, but an animal.
And baking powder? (chemical yeast in french)
No, it is not alive. It is just a mix of sodium bicarbonate and citric acid.
But what about dry yeast?
That one is alive. If you look under a microscope, you will see some cells.
Yeast is indeed a unicellular organism related to fungi.
A cat, a cucumber, corals and dry yeast, despite their different aspects are all made of living cells.
And if we would be able to dive and swim inside these cells,
we would probably have some issues to make the difference between each of them.
This is because all leaving cells share some common traits.
Their size may vary a lot both within an organism, and between organisms,
but they are all delimited in the same way:
A membrane made of two layers of lipids.
It is a first example of a common trait to all living organisms.
What you find within each cell depends on the species of course,
but there are several processes that can always be found,
regardless if you speak about a human, a cucumber or yeast.
For example, cells need energy to work,
and this energy is stored in the same molecule in the entire living world: the ATP.
ATP, Adenosine TriPhosphate, is a molecule sometimes called the energetic currency of the cell
It is at the heart of metabolism in all living organism,
by being constantly transported, used, and replenished by the processes happening in cells.
Right now, in your body, all your cells contain in total few 100 grams of ATP
But during 1 day, you use and produce as much as your body weight of ATP.
ATP and its use in metabolism, that is another common trait found in all organisms.
And of course, another common trait to all living organisms is DNA.
This long molecule carries the genes thanks to the sequence of its bases. The famous A, G, T, C.
Thanks to this basic alphabet, DNA stores the genetic information.
In a cucumber cell as in a cell of Henry Cavill, DNA is made exactly in the same way.
As well, we find the same cellular machinery that allows its replication and its utilisation to produce proteins.
Indeed we find in a cell thousands of different proteins with specific functions.
Therefore, each cell needs to know how to produce the proteins that are vital,
and this is where DNA serves as a blueprint
A protein is always made of a chain of elementary components called amino acids.
There are 20 different ones, with names such as Leucine, Alanine, Cysteine, among others.
The blueprint of a protein, is in fact just the ordered list of amino acids needed to make it.
The link between DNA and the list of amino acids that compose a protein
is a set of rules named the genetic code.
The genetic code is a table that explains how to translate the order of base pairs in DNA
into the list of amino acids needed to build a protein.
One reads the DNA base pairs in groups of 3, and each group indicates which amino acid to add to the chain.
This translation table is the same for all living organisms, from yeast to you.
Remarkable, isn't it?
With all these common traits, we could say that we have our definition:
Life is everything made of cells in which there is DNA and the metabolism uses ATP.
But as always when we try to formalise the definition of  a natural phenomenon,
we end up finding things difficult to classify.
Let's have a look at viruses. Contrary to what one of these graphical representation would let us think,
viruses are not cells.
The structure that we see on such images is a capsid, made of proteins.
Within viruses, there is only DNA or RNA, and no cellular machinery nor metabolism.
In fact, the principle of a virus is that it has to infect the cell of another organism
to hijack its cellular machinery for its own DNA.
So should viruses be considered as alive?
Well, the question is a matter of debate among specialists
On one side they have genetic information in the form of DNA or RNA,
but on the other side they do not have a metabolism and cannot replicate independently.
One could find even more puzzling examples, such as viroids
which are single pieces of RNA, without any capsid surrounding them.
Or what about prions? Single proteins with the ability to infect other proteins by changing their shapes.
I already spoke about it on a previous episode on the topic. If you are interested have a look.
So our nice definition of Life could easily be questioned using these examples.
But actually, why do we need an accurate definition of Life?
Well, thinking about the definition of Life influences the way we approach the question of the origins of Life.
Indeed, we still do not know how Life appeared on earth 3 or 4 billion years ago.
What is the most important? DNA and RNA? Metabolism with ATP?
Cells with a lipid membrane?
Depending on how much importance we give to these criteria, the question of the origins of Life will differ.
Did life appear in freshwater, seemingly more suitable to the formation of lipid vesicles?
Or in clay, adapted to catalyse some biochemical reactions?
Or in deep hydrothermal vents, better suited for the metabolism?
Each of these propositions emphasise one of the aspects of the definition of Life as we know it.
But beyond the question of the origins of Life on Earth,
another field requests a very specific definition of Life: Astrobiology.
This field investigates if extraterrestrial Life exists, and how to detect it.
What is Life? (Astrobiology 1)
When we try to imagine what an extraterrestrial life form could look like,
we are often biased:
We imagine it as a slightly modified version of life on earth.
Green vegetation, quadruped animals, intelligent biped beings...
So nothing more than life on earth that would have evolved slightly differently.
But there is actually nothing that forces us to imagine extraterrestrial life as a mere copy/paste of life on earth.
If we focus on what I listed as the essentials of life as we know it,
we can easily imagine important biochemical variations.
Let's look at the amino acids within our proteins.
The name amino acid in general describes any molecule following this blueprint:
A carbon atom, often shown in the central position,
linked to one hydrogen,
a NH2 group, the amine,
and a COOH group, the acid.
Hence the name amino acid.
And on the 4th liaison of the carbon, we can put more or less everything we want!
Well, at least if it fits chemically.
It is called a radical.
With a simple hydrogen as radical, you get the amino acid called glycine.
With a CH3 group you get alanine.
With a CH2SH group you get cysteine, and so forth.
As we said, there are 20 amino acids in the genetic code and used in the living world.
But on a chemical point of view, one could imagine many others, just by changing the radical.
Actually we know how to artificially synthesise several hundreds.
So why would we not imagine some life forms based on some of these other amino acids?
This idea is in fact plausible as we know that many of these amino acids are fairly easy to produce in nature.
We found some in some experiments aiming at reconstituting the physicochemical conditions on earth 4.5 billion years ago.
For example in the famous Miller-Urey experiment.
Even better, some of these "exotic" amino acids have been found in some meteorites.
For example the meteorite of Murchison, fallen in Australia in 1969.
Within, we could identify among others the Norvaline, Isovaline, and the Sarcosine amino acids.
Yes yes, Sarcosine exists... (Sarkosy = former french president)
No one of these amino acids is part of the list of the 20s,
but we could perfectly well imagine some life forms using them to build there proteins.
All these variations of the biochemistry of Life could perfectly exist.
But maybe we are still too conservative, too influenced by Life as we know it.
What if we should imagine completely different chemical reactions?
First, life on earth is based on water.
It is used as a solvent, meaning a liquid in which various molecules can be dissolved ,
allowing them to meet each other and react.
But we could imagine different solvents.
I spoke about it on my video about water.
Other molecules such as ammonia, NH3, and methane, CH3, could in some conditions also act as a solvent,
and therefore as a basic medium for new life forms.
Take for example Titan, a moon of Saturn roughly half as big as earth in diameter
which has oceans, clouds, and rivers... but made of liquid methane!
There is on Titan a whole cycle of methane, as we have a cycle of water on earth,
and it is tempting to imagine on Titan living organisms chemically different from what we know.
Another interesting point:
Nearly all molecules that are involved in life on earth are made of only 6 elements.
Carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus and sulphur,
nicknamed CHOMPS.
These 6 elements are sufficient to make everything we spoke about: Proteins, DNA, RNA, carbs, lipids.
But what if we imagined some alternative biochemistry with other elements?
After all there exist more than 100 of them. Why sticking to 6 only?
To visualise this, we can use the table of Mendeleev.
Here it is, with the position of the CHOMPS.
You may know that this table is also called the periodic table of elements.
The reason is that in each column of the table, the elements have a similar chemical behaviour.
The first one contains the alkali metals, the second one the alkaline earth metals, the last one the noble gases...
So in general, if you pick an element, the one just under it is likely to form similar chemical bonds.
Therefore, to find some alternatives to the CHOMPS, we could select in the same columns.
For example, just under sulphur, there is selenium.
This element is not common, but chemically similar to sulphur.
Why not a life form that would use it?
Interestingly, life on earth is already partially doing it.
Remember, I said that there were only 20 amino acids that were used to make proteins.
Well, there is actually a 21st one, the selenocysteine.
This amino acid is exactly like cysteine, except for the replacement of the sulphur atom by a selenium atom.
Because these two are chemically very close, it works!
This peculiar amino acid is pretty rare, not even found in all living organisms.
Still, we know around 50 proteins in human that use it.
See, even life on earth can tweak its basic elements.
Let's get back to the periodic table. Under phosphor, there is arsenic.
Their positions show that they can have some similar chemical behaviours.
That is actually the reason why arsenic is so dangerous.
Indeed, phosphorus is a key component of ATP and DNA structure.
So if an arsenic atom takes the place of a phosphorus atom,
it can disturb the metabolism, as well as the replication of DNA.
This is why arsenic is both a poison and a carcinogen.
However, if a new life form would base itself on arsenic instead of phosphorus, it could potentially work.
In fact some scientists believed to have found this in a Bacteria 10 years ago.
The discovery created a lot of controversy, and after much critics, the publication was retracted.
So arsenic-based life is maybe not present on earth, but potentially on another planet.
Even more bizarre now. Under the carbon in the periodic table, there is silicon.
Remember that carbon is the key element of biochemistry.
With its 4 liaisons it can form a lot of various complex molecules,
and it is therefore at the base of all life chemistry.
It is also thanks to the liaisons of carbon atoms that we can produce plastic.
Plastics are indeed long carbon chains repeating always the same basic structure.
That is what is called a polymer.
Silicon, with its 4 liaisons, can also play a similar role as carbon.
For example, in industrial applications it allows to produce the polymers called silicone.
Silicone polymers are plastics with different properties than the polymers based solely on carbon.
So why not a life form entirely based on silicon?
After all it is one of the most abundant element on a rocky planet as Earth,
and some living organisms already know how to use it.
Diatoms for example, which are unicellular organisms able to build wonderful shells of SiO2, silica.
They basically make shells of natural glass.
A form of life based on silicon would mean that organisms could metabolise silicon-based molecules.
While breathing, these organisms would not produce CO2, but SiO2.
They would exhale glass...
Well, why not...
What is Life? (Astrobiology 1)
Among all the people who tried to define life in the most general way, there is NASA,
especially since the beginning of the missions towards Mars and the launch of the Viking probes in 1975.
It is easy to understand the importance of the question here.
If these missions aim at looking for Life, one should better have a good definition of Life.
This will of course decide which instruments are taken on board, the analyses performed, etc...
In the 90s, a research group from NASA proposed a new definition of Life,
with the advantage to be very general, but still usable.
Life is a self-sustaining chemical system capable of Darwinian evolution.
In this definition all words are important.
The word system shows that Life is not a couple of things here and there,
but a system of interacting things.
If we take a cell, and look at each molecule independently, we would not qualify them as alive.
It is the system as a whole that is alive.
The word chemical is broad enough to not suppose that water or carbon have a dominant role.
Self-sustained. Careful, it does not not mean that a living system can have perpetual motion.
Rather, it means that it can take from its environment the resources needed to its survival.At least temporarily.
Finally, the most interesting part: Capable of Darwinian evolution.
It is true that a characteristic of life on Earth is evolution based on natural selection.
Something Darwin understood without knowing the chemical mechanism involved.
Since Darwin, we have understood that in life on Earth, evolution is possible thanks to DNA.
Indeed, the genes which are essential to evolution are carried by our DNA.
But NASA's definition is vague enough to allow other mechanisms than the one based on DNA.
In fact, it is a good exercise to wonder what is need chemically to mimic the storage of genetic information.
To allow Darwinian evolution, 2 features are needed: Replication and mistakes.
The reason why DNA transfers hereditary information is its ability to replicate.
It is chemically possible to copy a strand of DNA to transmit it to the next generation for example.
Paradoxically, to allow Darwinian evolution, the copy should not be perfect. Errors are needed.
If not for errors, the genetic information would always be identically copied, and no evolution would happen.
Evolution is allowed by these errors, or mutations, which will sometimes create better adapted descendant.
These descendants will then be favoured by natural selection.
To store so much information on a chemical support, one needs very big molecules.
DNA and RNA for example are constituted of many elementary blocks.They are therefore polymers.
As said before, we know a lot of polymers. All plastics with the name starting with poly- are polymers.
Could any of these polymers be used to store genetic information? Probably not.
That is because there is one amazing thing with the molecule of DNA.
As said earlier, if you compare your DNA and the one of a cucumber, the general structure is the same.
The details however are very different.
The sequence of A, G, T and C bases are completely different... otherwise you would be a cucumber!
Despite this, you DNA and the one of the cucumber behave exactly in the same physical and chemical way.
They are processed in the same conditions by the same cellular machinery.
That means that DNA is a molecule to which one can change some atoms
without changing its physico-chemical properties.
Note that this is unusual. If you take a molecule and you change some atoms, you will get a new molecule.
This new molecule will potentially behave in a completely new physical and chemical way.
What explains this stability of DNA? e.g. This property to behave in the same way regardless the base sequence.
According to the biologist Steven Benner, the key element is the phosphate groups,
found in the skeleton of DNA.
More important is the fact that these phosphates are charged negatively.
This chain of negative charges in the skeleton
plays such an important role in the determination of physical interactions of DNA
that, whatever the bases used, the molecule will react in the same way.
That led Steven Benner to propose that in order to store genetic information
one needs a polymer with charged elementary blocks: a polyelectrolyte.
For him, to detect extraterrestrial Life, a system with Darwinian evolution,
we have to look for polyelectrolytes.
Steven Benner actually tried to make some synthetically,
to show how to make some DNA alternatives.
That is how in 2019 he published a polyelectrolyte that could be used as the support of information,
containing 8 bases instead of the usual 4.
With all these considerations, we have now a definition of Life allowing to look for a broad range of things,
without falling in the trap of looking for something too similar to life on Earth.
But what if we are still to conservative?
What if Life could take forms we cannot even imagine?
Forms that would emancipate themselves from chemistry as we understand it.
In 1964, when NASA started to wonder about what is Life in order to identify it,
the chemist James Lovelock told them:
"If I would be you, to find Life, I would look for entropy reductions."
Entropy, an idea often associated to randomness or disorder,
and for which the second law of thermodynamics says that it can only increase.
In the universe, there is more and more disorder.
However, it looks like Life freed itself from that law.
Structures that are more and more ordered, organised, complex...
Is Life going against the laws of thermodynamics?
I had already briefly mentioned these questions in my episode on energy and entropy.
At that time, I had promised to do a follow-up on the thermodynamic of Life.
So here it is, the bases are set, and in the next episode
we will try to understand how to define Life based on thermodynamic considerations.
Thanks for watching the video, don't forget to follow me if you like it, so that you do not miss anything.
You can also see the news of the channel on facebook and twitter,
and we see each other soon again to continue to explore Life.
